name: abies-firma
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: Is immune to the balsam woolly adelgid which can be a problem for other species of fir. It is resistant to phytopthora root rot.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: No fruits but produces cones. Seed cones are 3 to 6 inches long, conical, erect on branches and showy through the summer. In autumn, the cone breaks apart releasing the seeds and leaving only the central axis of the cone on the tree. The pollen cones are 1.3 inches long and droop from the leaf axils.
leaf-description: Needles 0.8 to 1.5 inches long, dark green, fragrant, flattened, spreading at nearly right angles from the shoot and strongly two-ranked. Needles are notched at the base and sharply pointed at the tip. They are bright green above, and greyish-green below with two, broad, longitudinal stripes.
bark-description: The bark is scaly grey-brown, with resin blisters on young trees. Becomes scaly, fissured and corky with age.
stem-description: Young branches are ascending but become horizontal with age. The shoots are grooved, buff to grey-brown, glabrous or finely pubescent
uses: Used as bonsai and Christmas trees. Wood is used for timber, flooring, crates, and paper pulp
